Free Music Free It's no great revelation to say that the music recording and distribution industry has a comprehensive track record of momentously stupid decision making and political alignment over the entire course of its history. The Music Business has long been the sanctuary of that not-rare-enough cross section of people incapable of succeeding in either music or business. Their truly ridiculous stance on the evolution of music file compression and sharing, while not without precedent (the RIAA represents many of the same corporations that were wetting themselves when radio began broadcasting), may be the absolute nadir of their collective cultural disconnect. If you are looking for some actual facts on the subject of file-sharing, try this report: urlLink The Effect of File Sharing on Record Sales - An Empirical Analysis by the University of North Carolina and the Harvard Business School. Here is a snippet (but please, read the whole thing, as I am an obviously biased opinion, and we all know editing is a kissin' cousin of lying) We find that file sharing has no statistically significant effect on purchases of the average album in our sample. Moreover, the estimates are of rather modest size when compared to the drastic reduction in sales in the music industry. At most, file sharing can explain a tiny fraction of this decline. ... The business model of major labels relies heavily on a limited number of superstar albums. For these albums, we find that the impact of file sharing on sales is likely to be positive, leaving the ability of major labels to promote and develop talent intact. Our estimates indicate that less popular artists who sell few albums are most likely to be negatively affected by file sharing. (Note, however, that even for this group the estimated effect is statistically insignificant.) ... File sharing lowers the price and allows an apparently large pool of individuals to enjoy music. The sheer magnitude of this activity, the billions of tracks which are downloaded each year, suggests the added social welfare from file sharing is likely to be quite high. Farce As Weapon of Mass Distraction To elaborate on my previously stated political stance, last presidential election I voted for the libertarian candidate. Not that I would consider myself a hardcore libertarian, but that particular brand of radicalism applied to today's current political scene would at least cause enough of a correction to move the system as a whole towards my current ideal. [rant] I was planning on following the same route this year. While I think Bush is a bad president, I was not particularly interested in any other candidate, and felt that it was more important to use my vote as an expression of disgust against the two-party system. Then, Bush chimed in on the whole same-sex marriage issue by saying he urlLink supported a constitutional amendment that would "honor marriage between a man and a woman, codify that". To give full disclosure, Bush said he believes that same-sex marriage is a state, not a federal issue, "except and unless judicial rulings undermine the sanctity of marriage; in which case we may need a constitutional amendment." Here is the part that pissed me off. Pissed me off enough to decide on the spot that I would vote for whomever I felt had the best chance of defeating Bush. "...undermine the sanctity of marriage...". Are you fucking kidding me? That is precisely what such an amendment would do! Not only that, it would undermine the sanctity of the urlLink constitution ! That can't be good for the country, can it? Here's the deal, as a heterosexual with a desire for marriage, I would like to insure that the institution of marriage maintains at least a modicum of honor and prestige, if for no other reason than so that I may enjoy those benefits when I myself marry. Allying marriage with the precepts of exclusion, intolerance, and discrimination would devalue and dishonor marriage far more significantly than allowing people who some might find abnormal to participate in marriage. If a constitutional ban on same-sex marriage is a reality at the time I marry, I will feel cheated. The second point, is that the constitution was founded as a document that grants basic inalienable rights. The only exclusions against people present in the US constitution are those related to the age, citizenship status, and country of birth (for President only) of elected officials; and restricting votes to people over the age of eighteen. That's IT! All other statements of exclusion on the constitution limit only the government. Adding an amendment to prevent certain people from a legal institution flies in the face of the entire cumulative history of the constitution. That is freakin' outrageous. [/rant] So in a nutshell, I'm voting for Kerry. And I feel incredibly dirty for doing so, but hopefully I'll one day be able to console myself with a wedding ceremony free of guilt, to a person of whatever gender, race, religion, creed, or status I choose. Free Music Free As you have probably figured out by now (you being the hypothetical people reading this blog on a regular basis, so far a total of zero judging by commentary (maybe it's because I haven't told anybody about it?)) (and yes, I just used sub-parentheses, and now I'm using parentheses in sequence. I'm ADD, get used to it), I spend a good portion of my life obsessing over the future of music distribution and the music industry in general. But let not it be said that I only criticize, and never propose solutions! Here is one concept I would like to see explored to handle artist compensation in the future. Here's the basic conundrum as I see it: In a digital world, possession of anything that can be rendered digitally is basically free. There's simply no getting around it, for reasons I started to type, but deleted as I got to page three and was still simply stating the conditions for my argument. Suffice it to say that if you don't agree with me, then you probably have way more faith in both technology and people than I do. If the product is free, how does the artist make money? The key (at least to my perspective) is that perfectly reproduced digital copies are free and easily distributed once they exist . So one solution would be to base artist income not on distribution, where there is no profit margin (if cost=zero and price=zero, profit ain't gonna be much), but on release. Hypothetical situation: People who like the music of an artist want to hear more of their music. If I listen to a song by Public Enemy and like it, I will most likely be willing to pay money to hear future songs by Public Enemy. Demand exists. Currently, PE capitalizes on that demand by releasing the music in a distributed format (CD). So when I purchase a CD, I am not paying for the songs on that CD, but instead for the convenience of having those songs made available to my location. No wonder the record label makes the majority of the profit, as they are the one providing the actual service. In essence, PE has given away their work to the record label in exchange for a (miniscule) slice of the profits from the label's work. Digital downloading basically destroys this model, as I can personally cut out the distributor, thus cutting off the profit source for both the label and PE. So what if PE were to realize that distribution is a dead economic model, and instead tie their profit potential to release. PE states on their website that they have composed a new song, and provide a title and perhaps a short sample. PE then sets their own price for the release of the song, to whatever they believe the song to be worth (much like a painter setting the price of a canvas at a gallery). People interested in owning this song make contributions to a fund. When the fund hits the pre-selected price point, the song is released in a digitally downloadable format. PE never makes another dime off of that song. This has two benefits. First, it deals with the reality of digital distribution, instead of trying to suppress an inevitable outcome. Second, it levels the artistic field into a more democratic, capitalist system. Currently, you have two options as a popular musician, rags or riches. There is no middle ground. The labels exist to produce stars capable of selling millions of records, and take no interest in anything else. This results in homogenized, music of the very worst stripe. Allowing artists to make a moderate living from releasing their music will discourage people with no interest in music, only stardom, and will encourage people with a love for music but without the requisite image required for stardom. It's not a perfect model by any means, and there are certainly many holes to poke. But I wanted to get a new solution out there for discussion, instead of just joining the millions who bitch & moan about the current system.

The premise is that a bunch of quantum physicists, neurologists, theologians and behavioralists get interviewed about such topics as quantum mechanics, brain topography, addiction and free will. Then a fictionalized account of these topics is shown by following three days in the life of photographer/recent divorcee (and extra-super-duper hottie) urlLink Marlee Matlin . View From The Well Right Brain/Left Brain Analysis from urlLink Mindmedia Sam, you possess an interesting balance of hemispheric and sensory characteristics, with a slight right-brain dominance and a slight preference for visual processing. Since neither of these is completely centered, you lack the indecision and second-guessing associated with other patterns. You have a distinct preference for creativity and intuition with seemingly sufficient verbal skills to be able to translate in any meaningful way to yourself and others. You tend to see things in "wholes" without surrendering the ability to attend to details. You can give them sufficient notice to be able to utitlize and incorporate them as part of an overall pattern. In the same way, while you are active and process information simultaneously, you demonstrate a capacity for sequencing as well as reflection which allows for some "inner dialogue." All in all, you are likely to be quite content with yourself and your style although at times it will not necessarily be appreciated by others. You have sufficient confidence to not second-guess yourself, but rather to use your critical faculties in a way that enhances, rather than limits, your creativity. You can learn in either mode although far more efficiently within the visual mode. It is likely that in listening to conversations or lecture materials you simultaneously translate into pictures which enhance and elaborate on the meaning. It is most likely that you will gravitate towards those endeavors which are predominantly visual but include some logic or structuring. You may either work particularly hard at cultivating your auditory skills or risk "missing out" on being able to efficiently process what you learn. Your own intuitive skills will at times interfere with your capacity to listen to others, which is something else you may need to take into account. My ex-girfriends would all whole-heartedly agree with that last sentence. Memo: They wouldn't call it Attention Deficit Disorder if it wasn't all three of those things.

Happy Birthday, Bugs. Feeelm Last night I rented the second disc of urlLink Six Feet Under: The Second Season and watched all three episodes. I really am starting to believe that the one-hour serial may the perfect format for cinematic storytelling. Most movies either feel stretched or squeezed to fit the preferred 100-minute box. The truth is, some stories should be told quickly, and other stories need time to develop. 1-hour TV shows allow you to accomplish both, as the multiple storylines let shorter arcs have quick resolutions, and the implied hold on the audience across episodes lets longer stories develop without feeling forced. I'm almost ready to include Six Feet Under among my exclusive list of television shows that can actually be considered "art", along with urlLink Homicide & urlLink The West Wing . Kickoff Flying in the face of all fiscal responsibility, I went ahead and ordered cable TV to be installed this Friday. Really, the only reason I need it is to be able to catch SC games this season. But I certainly have missed watching urlLink The Simpsons without the squiggly reception lines, and the added entertainment will be helpful in curbing rental costs, since I had to sell nearly my entire DVD collection for quick cash. I'm now only one couch short of being a couch potato. Litrachure Last night I went to my first meeting of a reader's group at the Olive Way Starbucks. Not a book club, this was just eight people sitting around talking about the books they either are reading or have just finished. Really fascinating ideas, especially when the talk wound around to religion (as talks are wont to do (and can you tell I'm on an alliteration kick today?)). Of course, afterwards I felt so incredibly nerdy that I had to go shoot heroin, hire a hooker, and steal some kids lunch money just to restore balance. Good times. Now Spinning urlLink Galatea 2.2 by Richard Powers The library filed this under Sci-Fi, and the cover art sure is trying hard, but nobody is convinced, least of all the author. This is Powers getting his self-referential "woe is the writer" novel out of the way. Rite Of Passage, professional obligation, last-ditch effort, or simply too good an idea to pass, for whatever reason every fiction writer of the past 50 years seems to have one of these on their resume. Not that there is anything wrong with that. As a matter of fact, I am really liking this book. The science of neural nets and artificial intelligence is developed in an interesting manner, although Powers hedges his bets both by dialing down the scope and casually blurring the line between explanation and speculation. Still, the best of the multiple threads in this book is still the present-day attempts of a multi-disciplinary scientific team to create an artificial intelligence capable of matching wits with your average mid-western undergrad (the phrase managing expectations may be overused in election years, but if the shoe fits...). The only time the book bogs down for me is in the endless ruminations of the author over his lost relationship. Hopefully, this emotional backgrounding will wane as the book moves forward. Inspirations One of the oft-quoted passages in the above book is from William Blake's urlLink A Poison Tree I was angry with my friend; I told my wrath, my wrath did end. I was angry with my foe: I told it not, my wrath did grow. Taking this excerpt out of context, I was reminded of one of my favorite quotes, mistranslated by Rafi Zabor (probably from some other source) out of urlLink The Gnostic Gospels of St. Thomas : If you bring forth what is within you, what you bring forth will save you.
